rows.text_10: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the sugar cubes on the table. This time, he is sure he hears a giggle. “One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “Five!” shouts a voice from under the table.
rows.text_11: Tlotlego bends down to look under the table. To his shock, he sees a complete tea set laid out under the table! There are the missing teacup, plate, biscuit, and sugar cube. FIVE!
rows.text_12: When Mama and Papa come home from work, they all have tea on the stoep. One, two, three of them having tea at the table, and two of them having tea below!
rows.text_2: Tlotlego counts the teacups as he takes them from the kitchen. “One, two, three, four, and one for Koko!”
rows.text_3: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the teacups down on the table. “One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “I only see four cups,” says Koko, “but we are five people.” “When I was in the kitchen before, there were five cups!” Tlotlego exclaims.
rows.text_4: Tlotlego counts the pretty little plates as he takes them from the cupboard. “One, two, three, four, and five! There’s a plate for each of us.”
rows.text_5: Tlotlego goes to the stoep and places the plates next to the teacups.“One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “I only see four plates,” says Koko, “but we are five people.”
rows.text_6: Tlotlego counts the biscuits as he takes them from the jar. “One, two, three, four, and five!”
rows.text_7_right: “One, two, three, four, and ... ?” “I only see four biscuits,” says Koko, “but we are five people.”

rows.author: Kirsty Paxton
rows.title: The one on the middle

description.eng: Khanyiswa is not the first born. She’s not the last born. She’s the one in the MIDDLE!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: I am the middle one. Not the first born. Not the last born. The one in the middle!

text_2.eng: The one in the middle can be easy to forget.

text_3.eng: And easy to leave out.

text_4.eng: But that’s okay because I am also the one with IDEAS!

text_5.eng: Look what I can make from just this cardboard box! A BEAUTIFUL house... with real doors and windows.

text_7_right.eng: My house has an extra special bed, and a MAGIC SLIDE.

text_8_right.eng: Some days my house is also a shop.

text_9_left.eng: And on other days it’s a VERY FANTASTIC show.

text_10_right.eng: Sometimes my house is just for me!

text_11.eng: And that’s the best place for me.

text_11_left.eng: And sometimes it’s a house for three! I am the middle one. Not the first born. Not the last born. The one in the middle!

rows.author: Melissa Fagan
rows.title: The best thing ever

description.eng: Muzi loves to build with his toys. But when he leaves them behind to travel to uGogo’s house, he discovers something very special about the world. And he learns something new about himself.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: Muzi loves to build things. He dreams of building the best thing ever.

text_2.eng: Once he built a shelter for his toys. But it wasn’t the best thing ever.

text_3.eng: Yesterday he built a bridge for his animals. It was a good thing. But not the best...

text_4.eng: Today Muzi is going to visit uGogo. He is sad. Without his toys, how can he build the best thing ever?

text_5.eng: At the bus stop, Muzi is amazed. He sees red things and blue things. Small things and big things. New things and old things.

text_6_right.eng: Muzi has a new idea for building the best thing ever.

text_7.eng: On the road to uGogo’s, Muzi finds many things. Long things and short things. Round things and square things.

text_8.eng: By the riverside, Muzi finds more things. Soft things and pointy things. Green things and brown things.

text_10_right.eng: While uGogo bakes for the hungry travellers... Muzi builds.

text_11_right.eng: Gogo, Gogo! says Muzi. The world is full of toys. Look what I can build.

text_12_right.eng: Oh, Muzi, laughs Gogo. A new house for me. This is the best thing ever!

rows.author: Sope Martins
rows.title: Teju's Shadow

description.eng: Teju is worried. Something keeps following him! What could it be?

licence.eng: © Book Dash, 2019. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1.eng: “What’s that?”

text_2.eng: Teju hides. “It won’t find me here!”

text_3.eng: He runs. “Why are you following me?”

text_4.eng: Leave me ALONE!

text_5.eng: Go away. Go away.GO AWAY! “Teju! What are you doing?” “It won’t go away!” “Your shadow?”

text_6.eng: “It follows me everywhere! It’s like a super secret spy!”

text_7.eng: “Well, there’s one way to make a shadow disappear...”

text_8.eng: MAMA!

text_9.eng: Later that night in Teju’s bedroom, the light goes off...  ...and then on. And off... ...and on. Teju can’t sleep.

text_10.eng: <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>   <<CLICK>>

text_11.eng: “What’s wrong Teju?” “It only goes away in the dark, but I’m scared of the dark!” Mum gives Teju a big hug. “Do you want to see something amazing?”

text_12.eng: OOOHHHH! AAAAHH!

text_12_right.eng: Mum and Teju make shadow puppets until he falls asleep.

text_13.eng: “Cool!” After school, Teju waits for Mum. “I’m bored.” Teju stands up, he jumps, he dances.His shadow does the same.

text_14.eng: When he goes to bed that night, Teju leaves his night Light on. “Goodnight Shadow!”

rows.author: Sanjana Kapur
rows.title: Paint Dat, Plant Day

description.eng: Avi enjoys plant day, music day and paint day, and being busy throughout the week. Join in as Avi potters about the house, in this book about noticing and recognising patterns.

licence.eng: © Pratham Books, 2021. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_1_right.eng: Avi stretches and jumps out of bed. Today is Plant Day.

text_2.eng: Mama takes out the seeds. Avi places them carefully in the pots. Small pot, tall pot, square pot. Small pot— Avi waters the plants.

text_3.eng: Avi washes the brushes. Papa mixes the paints. Today is Paint Day. Swish, dip, squash, swirl. Swish, dip— Avi loves mixing the colours.

text_4.eng: Today is Fixing Day. Mama and Avi tighten the screws on the table. Tighten, thamp! Tighten, thamp! Avi checks to see if the table is still wobbly.

text_5.eng: Today is Cleaning Day. Avi helps Mama and Papa dust everything. Dhup, wipe, cough, clean. Dhup, wipe— ACHOO!

text_6.eng: Today is Sheet Day. Avi is changing the sheets on the beds. Pull, tuck, pull, tuck, pat-pat. Pull, tuck—

text_7.eng: Avi lines up all the cushions and pillows on the floor. Cushion, cushion, pillow, bolster. Cushion, cushion— JUMP!

text_8.eng: Music Day is Avi’s favourite. No one stops the loud sounds! Dham-dhoom- japh, dham- dhoom- japh. Avi hits the drums again. Dham—

text_9.eng: It is Bird Day. Avi watches the birds with Mama and Papa. Brown bird, slow-walker, long legs. Brown bird—

text_10.eng: Avi yawns. He is tired but excited about waking up in the morning. Tomorrow is Plant Day again!

text_11.eng: Patterns Are All Around Us. The days, the weeks, the months, and the years always follow a pattern. Look at the days in your week. Is any day kept for a special activity? Make a calendar for yourself and fill it with the patterns you see.

rows.author: Sally Partridge
rows.title: Mama, What's For Lunch

description.eng: Join Thabo and his sister Tumi for magical lunches with Mama!

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1.eng: “Hurry,Thabo. Mama is making lunch,” calls Tumi.

text_3.eng: His friends don’t understand why he chooses lunch over their game, but Thabo has a secret. Mama’s lunches are special.

text_4_right.eng: On Monday, Mama shapes their food like little bugs that wriggle and crawl, making Tumi shriek in fright. “EEEE!” But they are yummy fruit and vegetables, and not very scary at all.

text_5.eng: On Tuesday, she makes a lion that roars so loudly the house shakes. “ROAR!” ut it’s just delicious pasta and cheese.

text_6_right.eng: On Wednesday, Mama creates a chicken that wakes up the whole street. “CLUCK CLUCK PAKAA!” But it’s just a plate of juicy fruit.

text_7_right.eng: On Thursday, she builds a noisy truck. Thabo and Tumi cover their ears. “VROOOM!” But it’s a sweet strawberry jam sandwich.

text_8_right.eng: On Friday, Mama makes a beautiful garden filled with flowers, birds and ladybugs. “TWEET TWEET!” But it’s healthy pap, beans and a crunchy salad

text_9_right.eng: “Mama, what’s for lunch?” asks Tumi. “Yes, Mama,” says Thabo. “What are you making today?”

text_10_right.eng: Thabo and Tumi can’t wait another second. Their tummies are grumbling. Finally, Mama is ready. “What is it Mama?” asks Thabo, licking his lips.

text_11_right.eng: It’s Thabo, Tumi and Mama! “Mmm, our favourite, your famous stew and rice.” “Thank you, Mama!”

text_12_right.eng: What will Mama make on Sunday?

rows.author: Sue Adams
rows.title: Let's go on a litter hunt

title.eng: Let's go on a litter hunt

description.eng: The yard is a mess. How will the children clean up?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_left.eng: Papa says, “This yard is a MESS. The wind blew the rubbish in.” Mama says, “Let’s go on a litter hunt. First look for tins.” Papa says, “Wear these gloves.” Yuck!

text_2_left.eng: We’re going on a tin hunt. We look up high and down low. We look under the bushes and against the fence.

text_3.eng: We’ve found red tins and green tins, rusty tins and shiny tins, clean tins and dirty tins. Yuck!

text_4.eng: What must we do with all these tins? Find a bin and put them in! Now look for plastic.

text_5_left.eng: We’re going on a plastic hunt. We look up high and down low. We look behind the chicken coop and in front of the house.

text_6.eng: We’ve found milk bottles and bottle tops, shopping bags and sucker sticks, straws and broken buckets. Yuck!

text_7.eng: What must we do with all this plastic? Find a bin and put it in! Now look for paper.

text_8_left.eng: We’re going on a paper hunt. We look up high and down low. We look near the water barrel and on top of the bench.

text_9.eng: We’ve found wet paper and dry paper, cardboard boxes and newspaper, old paper plates and dirty tissues. Yuck!

text_10.eng: What must we do with all this paper? Find a bin and put it in! What else can you look for? Hmm ...

text_11.eng: There’s no more mess! Wow! This place is so clean. Thanks, litter hunters.

text_12.eng: You deserve a treat! And remember ... what must you do with your litter? Find a bin and put it in!

rows.author: Diane Awerbuck
rows.title: How do you sleep?

description.eng: Can you sleep with one eye open? Can you sleep in a tree? Pula has a bed, but he wants to know how other creatures sleep.

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_2.eng: How do you sleep, bird? I fly in my sleep

text_3.eng: How do you sleep, bat? I sleep upside down.

text_4.eng: How do you sleep, bullfrog? I rest on my side

text_5.eng: How do you sleep, octopus? I change colour in my dreams.

text_6.eng: How do you sleep, duck? We take turns to guard each other.

text_7.eng: How do you sleep, baby owl? I sleep on my face.

text_8.eng: How do you sleep, otter? We sleep holding hands.

text_9.eng: How do you sleep, walrus? I sleep on the land and under the water.

text_10.eng: How do you sleep, giraffe? We sleep on each other.

text_11.eng: How do you sleep, meerkat? We sleep in a heap.

text_12.eng: How do you sleep, Pula? Good night! Sleep tight!

rows.author: Matthew Kalil
rows.title: Grandpa Farouk’s garden

description.eng: Amir loves Grandpa Farouk’s garden. But it’s dying. What can Amir do to help?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

text_1_right.eng: Deep in the city, surrounded by houses and bricks and tar, you’ll find Grandpa Farouk’s garden.

text_2_left.eng: Amir visits Grandpa once a week. He loves the leaves and flowers and trees.

text_3.eng: Amir helps to water the plants. He helps with the compost, and works with his Grandpa all day.

text_4.eng: When they finish, they feast on a harvest of fruit. One day, Grandpa didn’t eat his pear. “What’s wrong?” asked Amir.

text_5_left.eng: “My garden is dying,” replied Grandpa. “Why?” asked Amir. “Look closely,” said Grandpa. “Some pests are eating the plants.”

text_6.eng: “We need ladybirds!” said Grandpa. “They are the bugs that eat the pests that kill the plants. Without ladybirds, the garden will die.” “I’ll bring you a bug or two,” said Amir.

text_7.eng: For a whole week, Amir looked and searched and collected. He found one ladybird on the sports field.

text_8.eng: Two more at the shop. Three at the park.

text_9.eng: And four behind the TV. Next week, Amir went to visit Grandpa Farouk, and showed him his jar of ten bugs. “You’ve done well, oh my boy, you’ve done well,” Grandpa said, with a tear in his eye.

text_10_left.eng: Grandpa was very happy. The ladybirds were very hungry!

text_11.eng: The ladybirds ate the pests, and the garden blossomed.

text_12_right.eng: From that day on, Grandpa Farouk’s garden did what gardens should do. It grew and grew and grew.

rows.author: Priyanka
rows.title: Colours

description.eng: A white bear likes colours a lot, and he falls in love with new ones all the time. Join him as he explores a world of rainbows.

licence.eng: © Room to Read, 2015. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

rows.author: Veena Prasad
rows.title: Circles in the park

description.eng: Golu and Tama go to the park to play. What do they see all around them? This wordless book introduces circles, semi-circles and quarter-circles.

licence.eng: © Pratham Books, 2021. Some rights reserved. Released under CC BY 4.0 license.

text_6.eng: Circle Semi-circle Quarter-cricle How many semi-circles make a circle? How many quarter-circles make a semi-circle?

rows.author: Marion Drew
rows.title: Lefa's Bath

guidance_cover.eng: Discuss the book’s cover.  Ask: What do you see? What do you think this story is about?

description.eng: Lefa wants her bath, but where does all the water go?

licence.eng: This work is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Licence](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

guidance_1_a.eng: Ask your child: what is the girl doing? Why do you think she is doing that? What animals are those? How many are there?

guidance_2_a.eng: Mimic sounds and actions from the story, like the cows drinking the water.

guidance_3_a.eng: Say: oh no! Where has all the water gone? How do you think the girl is feeling?

guidance_4_a.eng: Use descriptive words to talk about the pictures. Say: she is pouring water from her yellow bucket into the large orange bath.

guidance_5_a.eng: Say: look! The ducks are splashing in the water! What do you think will happen next?

guidance_6_a.eng: Say: oh no! The bath has been emptied again! How did that happen? How is the girl feeling now?

guidance_7_a.eng: Ask: What is the girl doing now? What animal can we see coming closer?

guidance_8_a.eng: Ask your child: What is the pig doing? What is happening to the water? Can the girl see what is happening?

guidance_9_a.eng: Say: oh no! What happened to the bath now? How is the girl feeling?

guidance_10_a.eng: Use your voice and face to demonstrate emotions from the pictures. Say: look, she is crying? Why do you think she is feeling sad? How do you think the animals are feeling?

guidance_11_a.eng: Ask: what are the animals doing? Why are they doing that? Say: Can you count the buckets of water? Are they all the same colour? What colours can you see?

guidance_12_a.eng: Ask: How do you think the girl is feeling now? Why?

guidance_13_a.eng: Reflect on the story with your child. Ask: What did you think about the story? How would you feel if you were in the story? What would you have done?
